botanical_details.potentially_harmful: All parts may cause severe discomfort if ingested and the sap may irritate skin. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Helleborus can be rhizomatous, herbaceous or semi-evergreen perennials forming a clump of pedate basal leaves, or evergreen with erect, leafy stems. Large, bowl-shaped flowers are borne in loose clusters in late winter or spring

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thrives in neutral to alkaline soils but tolerant of a range of soils that are moist, fertile and humus-rich. Partial shade is ideal but can tolerate full sun. Provide shelter from strong, cold winds. Mulch annually in autumn. For more details see hellebore cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by seed sown in pots in a cold frame as soon as seed is ripe; propagate by division after flowering or late summer
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove faded or damaged leaves as the flowers emerge
how_to_grow.pests: Hellebore leaf miner, hellebore aphid, slugs and snails may be problematic
how_to_grow.diseases: May be affected by hellebore leaf spot or hellebore black death
